placeable.title: iOS 16.5 isn’t looking like a very big update so far.

contents.html: The first developer beta of the update was released today, and the biggest features so far appear to be a new sports tab in the News app and the ability to ask Siri to start a screen recording. Later betas could add more exciting features, but if you’re looking for major software changes, it seems like you’ll have to wait until iOS 17.
Speaking of which, hopefully Apple announces the dates for WWDC soon. Theoretically, that will happen soon; the company revealed details for the 2022 show on April 5th.

placeable.title: Maybe don’t buy The Last of Us on PC yet?

contents.html: Sony has broken its streak beautifully bringing its biggest games to PC. The Last of Us just arrived on Steam and 67% of user reviews are negative. Beyond crashes and excessive VRAM use, it’s not Steam Deck Verified and doesn’t run well there, despite game creator Neil Druckmann’s tweet last December suggesting it would “grace” the portable.
Guess that’s why Sony didn’t send journalists review codes until today!

quickAttachment.embedHtml:
I would avoid Last of Us part 1 on PC right now until it's fixed. Lots of reports of crashes and 60+% of reviews on Steam are "mostly negative." It also takes an hour to build the shaders on the Steam Deck and runs at under 30fps even on low / med settings as it's not verified pic.twitter.com/UNUY0oR2vW

— Tom Warren (@tomwarren) March 28, 2023

placeable.title: The Succession-lidar connection revealed.

contents.html: Watching the Season 4 premier of Succession, I remember asking myself, what’s up with this opulent mansion where the Roy children are plotting their comeback? Who lives there? Why so many statues? So many questions!

The answer blew my mind. The mansion, which is located in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles, is owned by Austin Russell, the 28-year-old co-founder and CEO of Luminar, the lidar manufacturer and autonomous vehicle software company. As ex-Uber CEO Travis Kalanick once said, “Laser is the sauce.” How true.

quickAttachment.title: The mansion in Succession’s season 4 premiere belongs to a real-life billionaire with a struggling company

placeable.title: March 28th, 2015: on this day in Verge history.

contents.html: Remember Pebble? Exactly eight years ago, Pebble wrapped up its Pebble Time campaign on Kickstarter, raising just over $20 million for its latest smartwatch and setting a new crowdfunding record.

Remarkably, that record stood until March 31st, 2022, when author Brandon Sanderson doubled it by raising an astonishing $41,754,153 for a series of four novels. Nonetheless, eight years later, the Pebble Time still sits in the #2 spot for most funded projects on Kickstarter.

entry.title: Pebble Time raised more than $20 million on Kickstarter

video.description:
Pebble is going back to Kickstarter to launch its new watch, Pebble Time, available starting today. The new watch is slimmer and curvier than Pebble's earlier models, and for the first time includes a color display and microphone for voice control. There's also a new software platform with a completely redesigned interface based around the concept of a running timeline. Pebble's ambitious goals don't end with this watch: it's launching a whole platform that aims to be the center of your connected world. It's going to have to attain those goals and more if it wants to remain relevant in the next generation of smartwatches coming this year.

Subscribe: http://goo.gl/G5RXGs

Check out our full video catalog: http://goo.gl/lfcGfq
Visit our playlists: http://goo.gl/94XbKx

I’m guessing we’ll hear more about Assassin’s Creed Mirage, but I’m personally hoping for details on the company’s troubled Prince of Persia remake.

placeable.title: These Tesla glasses have a drinking problem.

contents.html: You know how cups have this built-in feature where you can set them down on any flat surface? Well, what if they didn’t?

TIL Tesla sells a set of drinking glasses that are “designed with angular contours” and only sit upright in a matching stand. For just $75, you too can look like an utter doofus while you sip your añejo.

placeable.title: Apple’s Pay Later program contradicts its focus on “financial health.”

contents.html: The company has gone through with launching its Pay Later program even as the BNPL industry faces scrutiny for potentially encouraging spending and helping to land young users in debt. As I wrote last year:

Attaching something as risky as BNPL to Apple’s brand puts Pay Later at odds with the company’s goal of providing customers with technology and services they can generally feel good about. As the big quote from Apple CEO Tim Cook on Apple’s Ethics and Compliance page reads, “We do the right thing, even when it’s not easy.”

entry.title: The ugly economics behind Apple’s new Pay Later system

placeable.title: Baby pods are in this summer.

contents.html: One of the most interesting movies at Sundance this year was The Pod Generation, a sci-fi parable about raising humans inside of high-tech eggs that look like they were designed by Jony Ive. Now those outside the festival circuit can finally check it out, as it’s slated to hit theaters this summer.

entry.title: The Pod Generation envisions the future as an egalitarian dystopia of the soul

Behind the couple is a woman gazing down at them both while she tells them about what they’re hearing from the egg. placeable.title: Good luck out there Zelda fans.

contents.html: I was going to hold out for a next-generation Nintendo Switch, but then Nintendo decided to announce a Zelda-themed OLED Switch. Now I’m sat in a virtual line at the Nintendo UK online store, with 17,627 people in front of me. If you’re also preordering the new Zelda Switch of your dreams, good luck!

caption.html: At least I can cook my dinner while I wait.
caption.plaintext: At least I can cook my dinner while I wait.

placeable.title: Another hurdle for AI image generators: unicycles

contents.html: Journalist Luke Bailey makes the point on Twitter with some fantastic images. (And our own try below.)
As with AI hands, this is likely an artifact of how these systems learn to recreate surfaces, not underlying structures, which makes objects with specific compositions (hands, unicycles) a challenge.

Sadly, wonky unicycles are not a useful tell when it comes to spotting AI fakes like the Pope in a puffy jacket. Not, of course, unless we demand all public figures conduct interviews on unicycles to prove the footage is real...

caption.html: Prompt: “Pope Francis riding a unicycle.” Generated with Midjourney.
caption.plaintext: Prompt: “Pope Francis riding a unicycle.” Generated with Midjourney.

asset.title: An AI generated image of the pope riding a badly rendered unicycle.

placeable.title: This is how you know you’re dealing with a different kind of music app.

contents.html: My favorite part of Apple’s FAQ about the new Apple Music Classical app is this repudiation of shuffle — from the company that named an iconic music player after the word. Classical fans prefer to not have their movements broken up, thank you very much.
Reminder: while Classical itself doesn’t support offline downloads, you can download any album or playlist you’re enjoying from the regular Apple Music app.

placeable.title: Elemental’s first trailer is a bubbling, sizzling feast for the eyes

dek.html: In its first trailer, Pixar’s upcoming Elemental tells a familiar story with some dazzlingly gorgeous visuals.
